newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS - JULY 9.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS - JULY 9.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--Athens and Ankara agreed on a set of principles designed to avert further tension and to govern Greek-Turkish relations on the sidelines of the NATO summit in Madrid yesterday, the result of intensive diplomatic activity by the US. While the government believes the six-point agreement satisfies all its conditions, leader of main opposition New Democracy Costas Karamanlis said a number of points in the agreement were open to interpretation and could lead to increased claims by Ankara.

--Direct talks between Cypriot President Glafcos Clerides and Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash begin in New York today with both sides pessimistic about making substantial progress to find a solution to the Cyprus problem. US presidential emissary on the issue Richard Holbrooke said yesterday that he considered the talks to be "back up" to his own efforts planned for next year.

--The health sector continues to be plagued by industrial action: hot on the heels of a recent strike by state hospital doctors - the fate of which will be decided today - pharmacists said they would shut down for a week.
--It is hoped the Madrid summit agreement will play the role of "firefighter" in the Aegean and pave the way for some kind of progress in the Cyprus talks beginning in New York today.
--The destruction of the Seih-Sou forest near Thessaloniki by fire over the weekend has now left the city open to the danger of flash flooding when winter rolls round.
--The government clarified yesterday that the Madrid summit agreement had not compromised its right to extend its territorial waters to 12 miles under the Law of the Sea convention.
--There's tension between Church and State over the government's desire to see a mosque begin operating in a suburb of Athens in which many Moslems reside. ELEFTHEROS TYPOS

--Investigating magistrates will begin hearing testimony from those implicated in charges of irregularities in the placing of a contract for a million digital switches for the Greek telecoms organisation OTE with Siemens and Intracom in 1994.
--Athens said it was pleased with the Madrid summit, saying it upgraded the country's role in the Balkans and paved the way for a resolution of the Cyprus problem.
